race.name: Crusher in the Tushar
race.tagline: The toughest 70 miles on the planet. 10,000ft of climbing. Finish at 10,400ft elevation.

vitals.registration: Jan 9 (deferral), Jan 16 (Life Time members), Jan 23 (general). Qualifies winners for Unbound Gravel.. Cost: $200

climate.description: July at 10,000+ feet means intense sun, thin air, and afternoon thunderstorms

terrain.primary: Mixed surface climbing with extended descents
terrain.surface: Gravel roads, paved climbs, technical mountain descents

gravel_god_rating.tier_note: Iconic gravel race with legendary difficulty - prestige override applied

logistics.explanation: Life Time runs tight logistics with a strict 10:00 AM cutoff at mile 27 - miss it and you're done. Field size caps at 600-800 riders with registration opening in January and selling out fast. The mountain-top finish at Eagle Point requires shuttle coordination that gets complex when slower riders are still grinding up Col d'Crush late in the day.

length.explanation: At 69 miles, it hits the endurance sweet spot without crossing into ultra territory. Paige notes the importance of pacing: "I have very little experience at altitude, and my priority for this race was not to blow up and to pace well." Winners clear it in under 4 hours while mortals take 8-9, showing how altitude and elevation turn every mile into a time thief.

technicality.explanation: Burke Swindlehurst describes the surface variety: "Everything from hard-pack dirt that's nearly as smooth as asphalt to intermittent stretches of golf-ball size rocks, to ball-bearing 'pea' gravel." The Big Drop descent sheds water bottles on washboards, while loose gravel on steep climbs makes "it pretty much impossible to pedal out of the saddle."

elevation.explanation: Over 10,000 feet of climbing across two mountain passes, each topping 10,000 feet elevation. The first climb gains 4,000 feet over 13-14 miles from Beaver Canyon, then after the plunge into Piute Valley comes Col d'Crush for the finale. This represents 140+ feet of climbing per mile average - among the hilliest profiles in gravel racing.

climate.explanation: Community reports confirm brutal heat swings - temperatures hit 95°F in the valleys while riders face potential "rain/snow mix up top." One rider warns: "It was really hot down in the valley and even tho there were aid stations, I saw a few riders run out of water between them." The desert-to-alpine transition creates multiple climate zones in one race.

altitude.explanation: The finish line sits above 10,400 feet - potentially the highest-elevation gravel finish in North America. Starting at 5,900 feet in Beaver, riders climb to over 10K twice, which means sea-level warriors get a physics lesson in oxygen debt. This altitude component separates Crusher from lower-elevation gravel events and favors altitude-adapted athletes.

adventure.explanation: Two 10,000-foot mountain passes, a 4,000-foot plunge through the Big Drop, and a mountain-top finish above the clouds create proper expedition racing. Burke Swindlehurst's course throws "the proverbial 'kitchen sink'" at riders - from smooth hardpack to "washboards severe enough to rattle tooth fillings loose." It's earned expedition status through terrain variety alone.

prestige.explanation: Founded by Burke Swindlehurst and formerly part of the Life Time Grand Prix, drawing elite fields including Keegan Swenson's sub-4-hour course record. Zach Calton's race report shows the tactical racing: "I went to the front and kept a hard tempo. I knew I was in good shape and had good preparation for this course and the altitude." The competitive depth validates its "toughest 70 miles" reputation.

race_quality.explanation: Well-executed with 5 aid stations, drop bag service, and shuttle support to the mountain finish. The mid-race cutoff at mile 27 by 10:00 AM is strictly enforced for safety on the remote mountain course. Life Time's takeover in 2019 maintains Burke's organizational standards while adding professional event management infrastructure.

experience.explanation: The Col d'Crush final climb creates lasting memories - riders describe the mental and physical breaking point of that never-ending ascent to 10,000+ feet. Zach Calton captures the intensity: "I looked back every few minutes and found a smaller and smaller group in tow." The contrast of valley heat, alpine suffering, and mountain-top finish creates an unforgettable bucket-list experience.

community.explanation: Smaller field (~600) creates intimacy. Serious athletes who know what they signed up for. The finish at Eagle Point has a party atmosphere with beer and food. Burke's presence and enthusiasm set the tone. Less 'festival' vibe than big races, more shared suffering.

field_depth.explanation: Elite-level competition attracts climbers and altitude-adapted athletes across 600-800 rider fields. Zach Calton's tactical racing shows the depth: "Once we turn off the main highway and start the initial climb proper I went to the front and kept a hard tempo." The combination of technical terrain and extreme elevation draws the sport's strongest mountain racers and separates pretenders quickly.

value.explanation: Around $200 entry for a premium, well-supported mountain event with aid stations, shuttles, drop bags, and post-race party at Eagle Point. The community appreciates the challenge itself as value - riders note the beauty and uniqueness of the course. Burke's self-imposed field cap "in the interest of keeping it manageable" maintains quality over profit maximization.

expenses.explanation: Rural Utah keeps costs reasonable but remoteness adds travel complexity. Riders recommend specific gearing - Paige used "a 46t front chainring and a SRAM Eagle 10-50t rear cassette" while others suggest "34-34" or "38-36 for my easiest gears." Limited Beaver lodging means booking early or staying 30+ minutes away, plus the Salt Lake City flight and 3-hour drive.

biased_opinion.summary: Crusher is what happens when you take a mountain stage of the Tour and add gravel. It's not for everyone—flat-landers and non-climbers will suffer disproportionately. But if you love vertical and want to test yourself against thin air, this is your race.
strengths: The scenery: Tushar Mountains are criminally underrated. World-class alpine beauty.
The challenge: Pure climbing race with technical descents. Rewards complete cyclists.
The field: Strong pro attendance brings legitimacy and race-day energy.
weaknesses: Altitude: If you can't acclimatize, you can't compete. Period.
Logistics: Beaver, Utah isn't exactly a travel hub. Plan for a road trip.
The climbing: 10,000 feet in 69 miles is relentless. Recovery from this takes time.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: If you're a climber looking for a gravel race that plays to your strengths, Crusher is your Super Bowl. If you're not—this will humble you.

final_verdict.one_liner: The climber's gravel race—where thin air separates pretenders from contenders.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you love climbing and want a race that rewards it, absolutely. If you're a diesel-engine flat-lander, consider something else. The altitude alone makes this a specialist's race.
final_verdict.alternatives: If you want climbing without altitude: Leadville (higher but different format). If you want gravel without the vertical: SBT GRVL Green offers similar beauty with less suffering per mile.

logistics.airport: Salt Lake City (SLC) - 3+ hours to Beaver
logistics.lodging_strategy: Beaver has limited hotels. Book early. Consider Cedar City (45 min south) for more options.
logistics.food: Pack essentials. Beaver is a small town with limited options.
logistics.packet_pickup: Friday evening in Beaver. Expo is intimate but covers essentials.
logistics.parking: Start area parking is manageable. Arrive 60+ minutes early for setup.

history.origin_story: Created by former pro cyclist Burke Swindlehurst: 'The ultimate race—too much dirt for road bike, too much road for mountain bike. If anyone could even finish it, they would be absolutely crushed.' 20 years of route development. 69 miles, 10,500 ft vertical = crushing profile. Starts historic downtown Beaver, finishes at Eagle Point Resort upper lodge (10,500 ft). 40% tarmac / 60% dirt & gravel.
notable_moments: Started as a 70-mile gravel/road hybrid before gravel racing exploded
Was part of Life Time Grand Prix in 2024 (dropped for 2025+)
history.reputation: The climber's gravel race. Where road fitness meets mountain bike descending.

course_description.character: Relentless vertical. You climb for 35 miles, then descend for 35 miles. Simple math, brutal execution.

suffering_zones.label: First Dirt Sector
suffering_zones.desc: Challenging 21-mile climb begins. The first dirt sector where elevation gain starts in earnest. Technical climbing through Fishlake National Forest.

suffering_zones.label: The Big Drop
suffering_zones.desc: Descent of switchbacks. Washboard-filled terrain. Loses 4,000 feet in 10 miles. Technical descending that tests your focus and bike handling.
suffering_zones.terrain_detail: 4,000 ft descent in 10 miles, switchbacks, washboard

suffering_zones.label: Doc Springs Road
suffering_zones.desc: 'Deceivingly uphill, rutted, and at times loose and sandy.' The time of reckoning. Doubles back toward Circleville. Mental challenge after Big Drop.

suffering_zones.label: Final Climb to Eagle Point
suffering_zones.desc: 1,000 feet climb on pavement to 10,500 ft finish. Eagle Point upper lodge awaits. Post-race lunch at summit. 'Your first Crusher is the hardest, and then they just keep getting harder after that.'
suffering_zones.terrain_detail: 1,000 ft paved climb to 10,500 ft summit finish

course_description.signature_challenge: The altitude. 10,000+ feet average means your power is down 10-15%. Plan accordingly.

videos.title: 2017 Crusher in the Tushar - Beaver, Utah, USA - The Gravel Race at Altitude
videos.description:
July 8, 2017 marked the 7th running of Crusher in the Tushar, a gravel race held in the Tushar mountains near Beaver, Utah. Making this event unique is the high altitude and prevalence of extended climbing, which arguably makes Crusher in the Tushar one of the hardest gravel races on the planet, despite being 70 miles / 112 kilometres in length.

JOM and the Gravel Cyclist crew of Mr and Mrs K-Dogg flew in from Gainesville, Florida to contest the event... from sea level with no acclimatization. Yikes!

videos.title: Call of a Life Time Season 1 - Episode 3: Crusher in the Tushar (Women’s Race)
videos.description:
The riders fight mental and physical fatigue as they hit the halfway point of the inaugural Life Time Grand Prix in Beaver, Utah, at Life Time Crusher in the Tushar presented by The Creamery. As riders like Sarah Sturm and Haley Hunter Smith try to climb the Grand Prix standings, UNBOUND Gravel winner Sofia Gomez Villafane looks to defend her Crusher title across 10,000 feet of brutal climbing in the stifling July heat — a.k.a. “the toughest 69.9 miles on the planet.”

A film by Cold Collaborative

Executive Producers: Kimo Seymour & Michelle Duffy Smith

Directed by Shannon Vandivier 

Producers:
Bowen Parrish
Shannon Vandivier 
Chelsea Jolly
Rebekah Sands
Ryan Cross

Edited by Blake Campbell 

Assistant Editing by Tyler Domingue and Jill Garreffi 

Field Producer: Chelsea Jolly 

Consulting Producer: Payson McElveen

Cinematography by Bowen Parrish, Brian Freeman, Nathan McBride, Tyler Domingue, Chelsea Jolly, Austin Alvarado, Benjamin Kraushaar and Shannon Vandivier

Special Thank You to: 2022 Life Time Grand Prix athletes, the Life Time team and our partners at Mazda.

videos.title: Crusher in the Tushar
videos.description:
A mixed-surface smorgasbord of cycling, the "CRUSHER"  begins in historic downtown Beaver, Utah, the birthplace of famed outlaw “Butch Cassidy”. Featuring a 40/60 split between tarmac and dirt & gravel sectors, the 70 mile course accumulates over 10,000 feet of elevation gain and affords riders the opportunity to explore the stunning back country of Utah’s little-known Tushar Mountains and Fishlake National Forest.
Join us, July 13th 2019 for the 9th annual running of the notorious Crusher in the Tushar!

quotes.text: I don't think there's another event on the planet that packs more suffering on a per mile basis than this event. It kind of throws the kitchen sink at you out there - the elevation gain, the altitude, the heat, the surfaces you're going to encounter.

Mentally this is the hardest time of the race so far, right down in the valley between the towns, windy, got caught out here by myself. It's going slow enough now that the flies can kind of buzz around and land on me, kind of waiting for the buzzards to start circling up above.

key_challenges.name: Valley section between towns
key_challenges.description: The mentally hardest part of the race - mind numbing riding down in the valley, windy conditions where riders get caught out alone.

key_challenges.name: Final climb
key_challenges.description: A nasty little pitch at the end that reduces riders to granny gear, with flies buzzing around because you're going so slow. Half to three-quarters mile of brutal climbing to finish.

terrain_notes.text: A lot of loose gnarly gravel throughout the course that challenges riders on the climbs and technical sections.
The final climb is so steep it reduces experienced riders to granny gear, going slow enough that flies can land on you.

gear_mentions.text: Riders debating between 38mm tires, with some choosing gum wall tires as the preferred option for the course conditions.

race_day_tips.text: The valley section between towns is the mentally hardest part - be prepared for mind-numbing riding in windy conditions where you can get isolated.
Don't forget your brew bracelet - you need it to get your post-race meal.

additional_quotes.text: Don't forget your brew bracelet - you need it to get your post-race meal. I forgot mine so we're going to see how much mercy these guys have.
I always describe cycling as this traveling circus and a series like this really feels like it. You start seeing the same people at the same races and it's kind of nice.
A lot of people don't know about the reason this event is so popular because it's hard and you can finish it - they really feel like they become something.

rider_intel.search_text: Crusher in the Tushar is described as packing more suffering per mile than any other event, with 69 miles and 10,000 feet of climbing featuring loose, gnarly gravel throughout. The course has three main sections: an initial climb, a middle section with downhill and flats, and a final massive climb. The valley section between towns is mentally the hardest part, described as mind-numbing with windy conditions that isolate riders. The final climb is so steep it reduces riders to granny gear, going slow enough for flies to land on them. Riders debate tire choices around 38mm width, with some preferring gum wall options. The mountaintop finish and combination of elevation gain, altitude, heat, and challenging surfaces create what organizers call a race that throws the kitchen sink at competitors. The event is popular because while brutally hard, it's finishable, giving riders a sense of accomplishment.
